title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.7.10 Part 1 | 13-12-2021
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.text: Om Agyana Timiraandhasya Gyananjanishalakaya
Chaksharunmilitam Jena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
Nama Om Vishnupadaya Krishna Preshtaya Bhutale
Shri Mate Bhaktivedanta Swamin Nithinamine
Namaste Saraswate Deve Gauravani Pracharine
Nirvishesha Shunyavadi Pachatya Deshatarine
Jaya Shri Krishna Chaitanya Prabhu Nithyananda
Shri Advaita Gadadhara Shri Vasadi Gauravakta Vrinda
Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare
Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare
Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya
Narayanam Namaskritya Naramchaiva Narottamam
Deveem Saraswateem Vyasam Tatho Jayam Udi Rayet
In this session we will be discussing from the 10th
verse of the 7th chapter of the first canto of Shreemad Bhagavatam.
This particular verse is a very famous verse.
It's called the Atmarama verse.
Here the verse now.
Suta Vacha Atmaramashchamunayo Nirgrantha Api Urukrame
Kurvanti Ahaitukim Bhaktim Ittham Bhuta Gunoharihi
The meaning of this verse is
that there are all different varieties of Atmaramas.
Who are called Atmaramas?
Those who take pleasure in Atma or spirit self.
Especially those established on the path of self realization,
though freed from all kinds of material bondage,
desire to render unalloyed devotional service unto the personality of Godhead.

Lord possesses transcendental qualities and therefore can attract everyone including
liberated souls. So this verse has been explained by Sri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu to
Sri Sanatana Goswami in 61 different ways. It's an amazing verse that's packed with so
much of meanings. So in the purport to this verse, which is a very elaborate purport written
by Srila Prabhupada, he explains that how did Chaitanya Mahaprabhu give 61 meanings to this
verse. So Srila Prabhupada says, Lord Chaitanya Mahaprabhu explained this Atmarama shloka
very vividly before the Lord. So this is a very elaborate purport written by Sri Sanatana
Goswami. Therefore his chief devotee, Srila Sanatana Goswami. Lord Chaitanya points out
11 factors in this shloka. Atmarama, Munayaha, Nirgrantha, Api, Cha, Urukrama, Kurvanti, Ahaitukim,
Bhaktim, Itthambhuta, Gunaha and Harihi. 11 different terms which make up this verse.
Now each one of these terms has got multiple meanings. So combining the different meanings,
there are so many meanings of the verse that can be derived.
So this is a very elaborate shloka. Atmarama, Munayaha, Nirgantha, Api, Cha, Urukrama, Kurvanti,
SSR. So Lord Chaitanya says, according to the Vishwa Prakasha, Sanskrit dictionary, there
are seven synonyms for the word Atmarama. What are the seven synonyms? The first one
is Brahman, the Absolute Truth. The second one, Atma refers to body. The third
one mind the fourth one atma refers to endeavor the fifth one atma refers to endurance the sixth
one atma refers to intelligence and the seventh one is atma referring to personal habits next
Lord Chaitanya says the word Munayaha refers to again there are seven different meanings for the
word Munayaha first is those who are thoughtful Muni means somebody who's a deep thinker so those
who are thoughtful second meaning of the word Munayaha is those who are grave and
silent the third meaning is those who are ascetics ascetics means they have taken severe vows and they
undergo austerities penances the fourth meaning of the word Munayaha is those who are persistent
determined the fifth meaning is those who are mendicants mendicants means beggars the sixth
meaning is those who are sages and the last meaning in this series the seventh meaning is
Munayaha referring to saintly persons or Saints then the word Nirgranta here for the
word Nirgranta there are four meanings given the first meaning is one who is liberated from
nescience nescience means ignorance one who is enlightened spiritually may be called nirgranta
the second meaning is one who has no connection with scriptural injunction granta can refer to
scriptures so nirgranta can refer to one who has no connection with scriptural injunctions
that is one who is freed from the obligations of the rules and regulations mentioned in the
revealed scriptures like ethics vedas philosophy psychology and metaphysics in other words this
nirgranta in the second sense refers to fools illiterate people archins etc who have no

So, it is said here Lord Vishnu is powerful and his activities are so glorious
that he has created the spiritual world by his internal potency.
He has created the material world by his material potency
and by his all-pervading features, he is present everywhere as a supreme truth.
And in his personal feature, he is always present in his transcendental abode of Goloka Vrindavana
where he displays transcendental pastimes in all variegatedness.
Now, Lord Vishnu's activities cannot be compared to anyone else's activities and therefore,
the word Urukrama is applicable only to him.
Only to Lord Vishnu and nobody else.
Now, there is another term that is used that's called Itthambhoota Guna.
The last line of this verse, Itthambhoota Gunoharihi. In that last line, one term Itthambhoota Guna has got
different meanings.
The word Itthambhoota is transcendentally exalted because it means full of transcendental bliss.
Itthambhoota means full of transcendental bliss.
Before this transcendental bliss, the bliss derived from merging into existence of the
absolute Brahmananda, what is called as Brahmananda, becomes like a piece of straw in comparison.
Which means, Brahmananda or the joy of merging into the existence of the Supreme is insignificant
in front of the transcendental bliss derived by realization or connection with the Supreme
Personality of Godhead, Lord Vishnu.
